body:
Too bad there aren't unicode representations for \Bart and \Homer...

http://divisbyzero.files.wordpress.com/2010/07/screen-shot-2010-07-13-at-8-43-31-am.png

The real bummer is that while there is a jupiter unicode symbol, it is not a valid Python 3 identifier :)

There are tons of unicode that aren't valid identifiers...

Could the list be pure Json file ? 
Is there a way to revert unicode char to `\itsRepresentationInLatex`?  I tend to don't remember the command of char I don't know. 

> Where should I put the notebook that autogenerates the map between latex-> unicode?

Does it really **need** to be a notebook.

Nice, I like this idea, though I haven't tried it yet.

The rules for which characters are valid in identifiers are [somewhat complex](http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3131/#specification-of-language-changes), but it looks like it's mainly characters in the letter categories, not symbols. So no `\unicodesnowman`.

@Carreau it doesn't need to be a notebook, could be a script - but still where to put?

I think the list could be a pure JSON file, but I think it is nice to have it be in Python.

Yes, the rules for which characters are valid identifiers are very complex - in fact, this page:

http://www.dcl.hpi.uni-potsdam.de/home/loewis/table-3131.html

is supposed to list all of them, but it doesn't. I use the following function to test if something is a valid identifier:

```
def test_ident(i):
    """Is the unicode string a valid Python 3 identifer."""
    try:
        exec('a%s = 10' % i, {}, {})
    except SyntaxError:
        return False
    else:
        return True
```

This is my my notebook/script that I don't know where to put.

I'd say the tools folder is the best place, whether it's a notebook or a
script.
/tools/ ?
Despite the fact that we are less than a meter appart and posted at the same time, I need to say that Thomas's response and mine are independant.

OK great, I will add this to tools!

notifications@github.com> wrote:

Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo

OK I have converted my notebook to a script that autoupdates the actual file in place - located in tools.

Here is a simple example of this types of things that this PR makes really easy if you know latex:

I honestly think this will convert me to Python 3 :)

![screen shot 2014-08-29 at 7 25 28 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/27600/4091444/7a6f0b72-2f88-11e4-9a93-e36f5b6f6ae6.png)
Nice!
Thomas, will you do a demo of that tomorrow ?
Sounds like fun

That image does look very nice! So, you type something like `\alpha` and
the system turns it into the unicode symbol for alpha? My only problem is I
don't know the names of all of these greek letters; how do I write code if
I don't know how to make the symbol? Copy and paste?

-Doug

On Fri, Aug 29, 2014 at 10:35 AM, Thomas Kluyver notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Sounds like fun
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/6380#issuecomment-53883838.

> My only problem is I
> don't know the names of all of these greek letters; how do I write code if
> I don't know how to make the symbol?

That was my previous comment. Yes copy past work. I would like smth like `\√<tab>` to turn into `\sqrt`  or tooltip to show `√ (aka: \sqrt)` but that's more work.
I see a build failure...

It's a bummer that on linux, the unicode rendering of the composite characters is crap:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/57394/4096452/fec5f92e-2fc1-11e4-9ec1-e5da37de29a5.png)

It may have something to do with how I have my system configured, don't know. But I get the same result with both Chrome and Firefox, so it's not a browser issue...

Overall this looks like a great addition, and I only have minor comments in review. I wish there was a cleaner, programmatic way to test valid identifiers built into the language, but reading PEP 3131 wasn't particularly enlightening, so the brute-force test approach will do.

Before merging, there should be a document that basically contains the same data as is in the auto-generated symbols file, but nicely formatted for reading, so that users can learn what they need to type to get the various characters. For some of them it's pretty obvious (like greek letters), but for many others it's not. And it will be hard to auto-discover this, so we should provide a reference sheet for users.
But otherwise great work, excited to have it go in!

For checking if names are valid identifiers, there's a str.isidentifier()
method that should do the trick without eval or exec.

From dev meeting, `str.isidentifier()` does not work reliably and does not correspond to the list of identifier that Python 3  should accept. @ellisonbg can you give an example of character so that we could ad a test ? Would like not to open bug on python side so that we can start using "non-authorized" identifiers.
List of some identifiers : http://www.dcl.hpi.uni-potsdam.de/home/loewis/table-3131.html
It sounds like the comment that `str.isidentifier()` is broken was a miscommunication: `str.isidentifier()` is safe to use as far as we know.
I've fixed up the comments people made on this, and Brian has merged the changes. Merging once Travis gives it the green light.
What about lookalike characters, like Α (not to be confused with A)? How am I supposed to troll people with homograph variable names?
`\mttA` ;-)
wait, that's behaving like regular A, even though it's a different code point. Unicode's trolling me...
Yeah, when I tried searching the diff for Α it showed me every uppercase and lowercase alpha, in every variety. In Unicode, "case sensitivity" is a grossly naive thing to say.
